newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico sets price for Chihuahua-Pacifico track.
newsitem.headline: Mexico sets price for Chihuahua-Pacifico track.

text.p: Mexico set the price for the main track of the Chihuahua-Pacifico railway at 253.499 million pesos, the Communications and Transport Ministry said in the Official Gazette on Friday.
An earlier privatization effort of the Chihuahua-Pacifico was aborted after lone bidder miner Grupo Mexico offered just 201.79 million pesos for a 50-year concession of the line.
The ministry said in a statement it would now offer a 50-year concession for the Ojinaga-Topolobampo, a 945 km section of the 1,512.4 km Chihuahua-Pacifico.
The shorter selection does not include the La Junta-Ciudad Juarez track, which will remain in government hands, it said.
The concession for the railway, famous for its Copper Canyon scenery, includes 30 locomotives and 400 cars.

Ministry privatization coordinator Jorge Silberstein has said the winner of the Pacific-North railroad could choose to pay the price to operate the Chihuahua-Pacifico track. The winning bidder is scheduled to be announced on July 7.
The lone consortium bidding for the Pacific-North railroad is composed of Empresas ICA, miner Grupo Mexico and U.S. Union Pacific Corp..
Grupo Mexico has eyed the railway because it provides key transportation to some of the company's most important copper mines.
